Posts.Content: I have an appointment with a RO next week. In determining a course of treatment, how important is the tumor volume as reported in the biopsy?
Posts.Signature: age 63 3/1/2015 PSA 1.9, nodule noted on prostate 5/20/2015 biopsy (15 cores), ultra sound was described as normal, however 3 cores were positive prostate nodule: Gleason 3+3 in 1 of 3 cores, occupying 2% of the core, and 1mm right mid: Gleason 3+4 in 2 of 2 cores, occupying 13% of the cores, and 4mm
Posts.Title: Tumor volume and treatment

Posts.Content: I'm 63, and my PSAs during last 2-3 years have ranged from 1.5 to 1.9. In February 2015, my PSA was 1.9, but the DRE revealed a nodule. Had a biopsy in May 2015 and the physician noted that there were no abnormalities observed on the ultra sound. However, 3 of 15 cores were positive. Right mid: 2 positive, occupying 13 percent, measuring 4mm of the surface area of the core (3+4) Three samples near the nodule were taken. One was positive (2 percent and 1mm) and scored as 3+3. My urologist suggested I have plenty of time to make a decision, and planned to schedule a MRI and genetic testing (Oncotype DX). I also have consultations with a da vinci surgeon and a radiation oncologist. Also will send pathology report for a second opinion. Based on my very early research, LDR brachytherapy would be number one on my treatment list . Have I covered all bases or am I missing something?
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed, Am I on the right track?
